choices.text: Uterine artery → Arcuate artery → Radial artery → Basilar artery → Spiral artery
Uterine artery → Radial artery → Arcuate artery → Basilar artery → Spiral artery
Uterine artery → Arcuate artery → Basilar artery → Radial artery → Spiral artery
Uterine artery → Basilar artery → Arcuate artery → Radial artery → Spiral artery

questions.text: Arrange the following branches of the uterine artery in the correct sequence as they proceed towards the endometrium:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Uterine artery → Arcuate artery → Radial artery → Basilar artery → Spiral artery

 

  • The uterine artery is the main arterial supply to the uterus, arising from the internal iliac artery (anterior division). 
  • It traverses through the broad ligament and gives off a series of branches that penetrate the myometrium and supply the endometrium.

 

Sequential branching pattern:

 

  1. Uterine artery → runs along the lateral uterine wall within the broad ligament.
  2. Arcuate arteries → run circumferentially within the myometrium.
  3. Radial arteries → branch from arcuate arteries and penetrate the myometrium toward the endometrium.
  4. Basilar arteries → supply the stratum basale (basal layer) of the endometrium.
  5. Spiral arteries → extend into the stratum functionale, the superficial layer that proliferates and sheds during menstruation.

 

 

Physiological importance: 

 

  • Spiral arteries are progesterone-sensitive and play a critical role in endometrial perfusion and implantation. 
  • During menstruation, these arteries undergo spasm and breakdown, leading to endometrial shedding. In pregnancy, they undergo trophoblastic remodeling to ensure low-resistance uteroplacental blood flow.

questions.text: What is the expected growth velocity in a child after 4 years?

choices.text: Acyclovir and review after 6 weeks for a repeat test

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman approaches the clinic for HPV testing for cervical cancer screening. The HPV is positive for type 18 HPV. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Colposcopy and biopsy

 

HPV types 16 and 18 are high-risk oncogenic subtypes strongly associated with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) and cervical carcinoma. When a screening test detects high-risk HPV (especially 16 or 18), the next step is to perform a colposcopic evaluation of the cervix. Colposcopy allows visualization of abnormal epithelium using acetic acid and Lugol’s iodine, followed by directed biopsy to confirm the grade of the lesion (CIN I, II, or III). This diagnostic step determines whether treatment such as excision (LLETZ or conization) is required.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LLETZ: Loop Electrosurgical Excision of the Transformation Zone is a therapeutic procedure used after confirmation of high-grade CIN (CIN II/III). It is not the first diagnostic step. Performing it without prior biopsy can lead to unnecessary excision and scarring.

 

Option B. Acyclovir and review after 6 weeks: Acyclovir is an antiviral agent effective against herpes simplex virus, not HPV. Human papillomavirus is a DNA virus that is not responsive to antiviral therapy.

 

Option C. HPV vaccine: The vaccine is prophylactic and prevents future infection with HPV types 6, 11, 16, and 18. It has no therapeutic role once infection has already occurred. Therefore, vaccination at this stage will not help in treating the current infection.

questions.text: 34-year-old patient is undergoing laparoscopy for infertility. This image is noted. What is the likely diagnosis?

Choose the order in which the following steps of total abdominal hysterectomy are done:

 

  1. Clamp, cut & ligate infundibulopelvic ligament
  2. Clamp, cut and ligate uterine vessels
  3. Clamp, cut and ligate round ligament
  4. Open uterovesical fold of peritoneum
questions.solution:
Ans. C) c-a-d-b

 

Stepwise sequence in Total Abdominal Hysterectomy:

 

  1. Clamp, cut, and ligate the round ligament (c): This is the first structure encountered after opening the abdomen. Cutting the round ligament allows entry into the broad ligament and facilitates further dissection.
  2. Clamp, cut, and ligate the infundibulopelvic ligament (a): This step is performed if the ovaries are being removed. It contains the ovarian vessels, which are ligated to prevent bleeding. If ovaries are conserved, the ovarian ligament is ligated instead.
  3. Open the uterovesical fold of peritoneum (d): The uterovesical pouch is opened to separate the bladder from the lower uterine segment, preventing injury during later steps.
  4. Clamp, cut, and ligate the uterine vessels (b): The uterine artery and vein, branches of the internal iliac, are ligated near the cervix. This reduces uterine blood supply before completing vaginal separation.

 

Hence, the correct surgical sequence is: c → a → d → b

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 2, at 28 weeks gestation comes to the OPD for a prenatal visit. She has chronic hypertension that has been well controlled during this pregnancy. At the patient's previous prenatal visits, her blood pressure ranged from 120/70 to 130/80 mmHg. Today, her blood pressure is 150/100 mmHg and repeat is 152/98 mmHg. Fundal height is 24 cm. Urinalysis shows 2+ protein. A transabdominal ultrasound reveals oligohydramnios and a fetus with growth restriction. Compared to normal placental parameters, this patient most likely has which of the following hemodynamic changes?

choices.text: a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h
a, b, c, d, e, g, h
a, b, c, e, g, h

questions.text: A 25-year-old G2A1 presents to the Antenatal OPD at 9 weeks. List the investigations that will be done:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) a, b, c, e, g, h 

 

The routine first-trimester antenatal investigations recommended for all pregnant women are:

 

  1. Hb (Hemoglobin): To detect anemia, a common complication in pregnancy.
  2. Urine C/S: To screen for asymptomatic bacteriuria, which can cause preterm labor and pyelonephritis.
  3. TSH: To detect hypothyroidism, which can lead to miscarriage or developmental delay.
  4. FBS (Fasting Blood Sugar): To screen for pre-existing diabetes mellitus or early-onset gestational diabetes.
  5. Blood group & Rh typing: To detect Rh-negative mothers and plan for anti-D prophylaxis if required.
  6. VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory test): To screen for syphilis, which can cause congenital infection.

 

Tests Not Routinely Recommended:

 

d. TORCH: Not part of routine screening. Performed only if there is bad obstetric history, fetal anomalies, or intrauterine growth restriction.

 

f. APLA (Antiphospholipid antibody): Not routine; indicated only if the woman has recurrent pregnancy losses, thrombosis, or stillbirths.

questions.text:
A group of premenopausal women participate in a clinical trial for a medication injected as depot intramuscular injection used to treat endometriosis. Prior to initiation of the medication, all the women had normal premenopausal levels of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), FSH, and estrogen. The participants' hormone levels are recorded over the next two months, with the results shown below:

 

 

The observed hormone levels are most consistent with administration of which of the following medications?

choices.text: Clean the wound, administer tetanus and rabies vaccine
Clean the wound, administer only tetanus vaccine

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presents to the OPD with a history of a dog bite. Her neighbor’s pet dog has bit her on the leg. She is currently 10 weeks pregnant. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clean the wound, administer tetanus and rabies vaccine

 

Dog bite management during pregnancy:

 

  1. Wound care: Immediate and thorough washing with soap and water for at least 15 minutes is crucial. Apply povidone-iodine for local disinfection.
  2. Tetanus prophylaxis: Given based on immunization history. A pregnant woman should receive TT or Td vaccine if not previously immunized or if more than 5 years have passed since the last dose.
  3. Rabies prophylaxis: Rabies vaccine is absolutely safe in pregnancy and must not be withheld. Post-exposure prophylaxis includes:
  • Rabies vaccine on days 0, 3, 7, and 14 (and day 28 if needed).
  • Rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) if the wound is Category III (deep bite, multiple wounds, or exposure to mucosa).

 

Rationale:
 

The risk of rabies transmission is fatal and outweighs any theoretical risk of vaccination during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Only tetanus vaccine: Incomplete protection. Rabies prophylaxis is mandatory after dog bite exposure, regardless of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Antibiotics: Adjunctive measure only; not a substitute for tetanus and rabies prevention.

 

Option D. Reassurance alone: Unsafe and inappropriate; rabies is nearly always fatal once symptoms develop.

questions.text: A 34-year-old P2L2 is taking “Chhaya” for contraception. She has been taking it for 9 months. She reports to you that she has missed taking the pill for the last 2 weeks as she had been traveling and forgot to carry the pill with her. How many tablets has she missed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

Chhaya: A centchroman (Ormeloxifene) tablet — a non-hormonal, selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used for contraception. It is not a daily pill, unlike combined oral contraceptives.

 

Dosing Schedule of “Chhaya”:

 

  • 1 tablet twice weekly for the first 3 months (every 3 days).
  • Then 1 tablet once weekly thereafter for maintenance.

 

Interpretation: The woman is in her 9th month of use → she is on maintenance phase (1 tablet per week). She has missed 2 weeks of doses → 1 tablet per week × 2 weeks = 2 tablets missed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Would be correct if she missed only 1 week.

 

Option C. 7 & Option D. 14: Incorrect. because Chhaya is not taken daily; it’s a weekly regimen, not a daily contraceptive pill.

choices.text: Decreased serum sex hormone–binding globulin levels

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary mechanism of a combined hormonal contraceptive?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Decreased release of gonadotropins

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pomeroy's technique

 

Procedure: The Pomeroy’s technique is the most commonly performed method of female tubal sterilization (tubal ligation). It is typically performed postpartum or as an interval procedure.

 

Steps of Pomeroy’s Technique:

 

  1. A loop (knuckle) of the fallopian tube is lifted up with a Babcock’s forceps.
  2. The base of the loop is ligated using an absorbable suture (usually plain catgut or chromic catgut).
  3. The tubal segment above the ligature is then excised.
  4. The cut ends retract away from each other as the ligature dissolves, minimizing chances of recanalization.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Type of sterilization: Tubal ligation (female sterilization).
  • Site: Ampullary–isthmic junction of the fallopian tube.
  • Material: Absorbable suture (plain catgut).
  • Failure rate: Approximately 1–2 per 1000 procedures (very low).
  • Reversibility: Difficult, but recanalization is sometimes possible if enough tubal length remains.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salpingectomy: Involves complete removal of the fallopian tube, not just ligation and excision of a loop. Done in cases of ectopic pregnancy, hydrosalpinx, or risk reduction for ovarian cancer, not for contraception.

 

Option C. Tubal recanalization: A reconstructive procedure to restore fertility by rejoining previously ligated tubes. Opposite of Pomeroy’s ligation.

 

Option D. Parkland procedure: Also, a tubal ligation method, but differs in technique: 

 

  • The tube is doubly ligated and a segment excised without forming a loop.
  • Two separate ligatures are applied 1–2 cm apart, and the intervening segment is removed. Commonly used during cesarean section.

questions.text: A 2-day-old girl is in the newborn nursery with persistent crying, tremors, tachypnea, sneezing, and diarrhea. She was born vaginally and had been breastfeeding well until several hours ago when she became tachypneic. Her mother has poorly controlled schizophrenia and did not receive prenatal care. The patient's mother also had a positive hepatitis C antibody test during postnatal laboratory testing. On physical examination, the girl has increased tone in all extremities. Chest radiograph shows normal lung fields. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for treatment of the newborn's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methadone

 

The newborn presents with neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS), a withdrawal syndrome seen in infants born to mothers who used opioids (such as heroin, morphine, or methadone) during pregnancy. Symptoms include irritability, high-pitched crying, tremors, tachypnea, sneezing, diarrhea, and increased tone.

 

Methadone is the treatment of choice for opioid withdrawal in neonates as it provides gradual weaning from dependence, reducing withdrawal severity and complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flumazenil: This is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist used for benzodiazepine overdose; it has no role in opioid withdrawal and may cause seizures in dependent infants.

 

Option B. Folic acid: It prevents neural tube defects when taken during pregnancy; it has no therapeutic role in neonatal withdrawal management.

 

Option D. Naloxone: It reverses acute opioid toxicity (e.g., respiratory depression) but is contraindicated in neonates with chronic in utero exposure, as it can precipitate severe withdrawal.

choices.text: Alveolar ducts lined with hyaline membranes
Giant cell foreign body response in the lower lobe of the right lung
Pulmonary artery branch with swirls of fetal squamous cells

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 40 weeks gestation has a protracted labor course for which a cesarean delivery is performed under epidural anesthesia. Shortly after delivery, the patient has chest pain and difficulty breathing. She becomes hypotensive, bradycardic, hypoxic, and unresponsive, and undergoes emergency intubation. The surgical incisions begin to bleed profusely and the patient goes into cardiorespiratory arrest. She is declared dead after 30 minutes of cardiopulmonary resuscitation. The family agrees to an autopsy. Which of the following is the most likely finding during histologic evaluation of her lungs?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Pulmonary artery branch with swirls of fetal squamous cells

questions.text: Which of the following is not included as a component of Jones criteria for diagnosing acute rheumatic fever?

A 37-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 1, at 28 weeks gestation comes to the OPD due to loss of urine with cough. She reports fetal movement and has had an uneventful pregnancy. Several years ago she had a spontaneous vaginal delivery of a 3.5-kg infant. Her pre-pregnancy BMI is 32 kg/m². Urine culture is negative. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism for this patient's urinary incontinence?
According to DeLancey's classification of pelvic organ support, the uterosacral ligaments contribute to which level of pelvic support?

A 33-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the OPD due to infertility. The patient also has a history of pelvic pain that worsens with menses. The pain has persisted despite medical therapy and is suspected to be due to endometriosis. Exploratory laparoscopy is performed, and multiple nodules, along with thin, filmy adhesions, are present throughout the pelvis. Several biopsies are obtained. In addition to having endometrial glands with hemosiderin pigment, one of the samples contains simple cuboidal epithelial cells. Which of the following is the most likely site of the biopsy?

A newborn boy is brought to the nursery for evaluation after delivery. The mother received no prenatal care but reports that the pregnancy was uncomplicated and she was healthy. The infant was born via spontaneous vaginal delivery and required no resuscitation. On examination, the infant is below the 3rd percentile for weight, 25th percentile for length, and 50th percentile for head circumference. Hepatosplenomegaly is present on examination. Over the next 48 hours, the infant develops jaundice, clear rhinorrhea, and a maculopapular rash on the feet and buttocks that later desquamates. Which of the following congenital infections is most likely in this patient?

A newborn is being evaluated in the nursery. The patient was born at term via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 23-year-old woman. The mother developed dark terminal facial hair and a deepened voice during the pregnancy. The delivery was unremarkable, and the patient’s vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows ambiguous genitalia and clitoromegaly. Laboratory studies reveal elevated serum levels of testosterone and androstenedione. Karyotype testing shows a 46,XX genotype. Ultrasound of the pelvis shows a normal-sized uterus. This infant's presentation is most likely due to deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
An 8-day-old neonate presents with jaundice. Which of the following is least likely to be the cause of jaundice after the first week of life?

A 16-year-old girl comes to the OPD for evaluation of painful menstrual periods. The patient underwent menarche at age 13 and initially had irregular menses. Her menstrual cycles now occur every 30 days, with 4 days of moderate bleeding. Her menses have become increasingly painful; lower abdominal pain starts a few hours prior to menses and lasts 1 or 2 days with associated fatigue, dizziness, and diarrhea. She misses school at least 1 day per month due to the pain but is able to maintain her grades and has no pain or other symptoms after completion of menses. The patient has a history of depression, for which she sees a therapist, but has had no recent changes in mood. Her last menstrual period was a week ago. Vital signs are normal. Pelvic examination shows normal external genitalia and a clear discharge emerging from the cervical os. On bimanual examination, the uterus is mobile, nontender, and normal in size and contour. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Attempt IUD removal by means of an IUD hook or long artery forceps
Continue the exam by twirling a cytologic brush in her endocervical canal

questions.text: Ms. T visits the OPD for a routine check-up. She had a copper-containing IUD inserted 6 months ago and is now concerned because she cannot feel the thread. Her LMP was 2 weeks ago. On speculum examination, the IUD threads are not visible (as shown in the image). What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Obtain a trans vaginal ultrasound

 

Clinical situation:

 

  • The patient’s IUD strings are not visible — a missing IUD thread situation.
  • The possible causes include:
  1. Strings curled up in the cervical canal.
  2. Expulsion of IUD.
  3. Pregnancy with IUD in situ.
  4. Perforation with IUD migration into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Stepwise Management Algorithm for Missing IUD Strings:

 

Step 1: Rule out pregnancy

 

  • Obtain urine β-hCG test → if positive, manage as per pregnancy with IUD.

 

Step 2: Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS)

 

  • Most appropriate first investigation for locating the IUD.
  • TVS can confirm whether: IUD is in the uterine cavity (proper position or displaced), Expelled, or Perforated through the uterine wall.

 

Findings and Further Management:

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Obtain a KUB radiograph: Only indicated after TVS fails to visualize the IUD, to locate an extrauterine IUD (e.g., perforation into peritoneal cavity).

 

Option C. Attempt IUD removal with IUD hook or artery forceps: Should not be done blindly — risk of uterine or cervical trauma. Only appropriate after confirming intrauterine location by imaging.

 

Option D. Cytologic brush to locate threads: Gentle brushing may be tried if ultrasound confirms intrauterine IUD, but not before confirming its position. Here, TVS is the safest next step.

questions.text: Preclampsia is due to decreased activity of which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Vascular endothelial growth factor

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, comes to the OPD for an initial prenatal visit. The patient has had no vaginal bleeding or abdominal pain and has not yet felt fetal movement. The patient’s estimated gestational age based on her last menstrual period is 16 weeks. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus that is controlled with insulin. She smokes a pack of cigarettes daily. As part of her prenatal laboratory screening, a second-trimester maternal serum quadruple screen is performed and reveals an elevated alpha-fetoprotein level. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's abnormal screening result?

You are called to the nursery to evaluate a newborn infant. The mother is a 24-year-old primigravida. The infant was delivered at 39-weeks gestation via emergent cesarean section due to maternal hypertension and non-reassuring fetal heart tones. On examination, the infant's weight is 2.6 kg placing him in the 5th percentile, height is 18 inches (46 cm) placing him in the 5th percentile, and head circumference is 13 inches (33 cm) placing him in the 10th percentile. The infant's head seems large for his body. There is a paucity of subcutaneous fat. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. This infant is at risk for having which of the following?

A 30-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the OPD for evaluation of infertility. The patient has been attempting to conceive for the past 2 years. Menarche was at age 11, and her menstrual cycles occur 2-3 times per year and last 7-10 days. BMI is 35 kg/m². Physical examination shows mild acne and hair growth on the upper lip and chin. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endometrial carcinoma

 

  • This patient’s presentation is classic for Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS).
  • Key diagnostic clues:
    • Oligomenorrhea / anovulation: Menstrual cycles only 2–3 times per year
    • Hyperandrogenism: Acne, hirsutism (upper lip, chin)
    • Obesity: BMI 35 kg/m²
    • Infertility: Due to chronic anovulation

 

Pathophysiology Link to Endometrial Carcinoma:

 

  • In PCOS:
    • Anovulation → lack of progesterone from corpus luteum
    • Unopposed estrogen exposure → continuous stimulation of endometrial proliferation
    • Leads to endometrial hyperplasia → can progress to endometrial carcinoma (type I, estrogen-dependent).
    • Hence, the greatest long-term risk = Endometrial carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenal atrophy: Occurs with exogenous corticosteroid use → not in PCOS.

 

Option B. Cushing syndrome: Can mimic PCOS (hirsutism, obesity), but PCOS itself does not cause Cushing; cortisol levels are normal.

 

Option C. Ovarian carcinoma: Ovaries are enlarged with multiple cysts in PCOS, but the risk of ovarian cancer is not significantly increased; main malignancy risk is endometrial.

 

Summary Table:

questions.solution: Ans. D) Classical congenital heart disease is VSD

questions.solution: Ans. B) Encourage the use of feeding bottles and pacifiers in the early postnatal period

choices.text: It is associated with obesity and diabetes

questions.text: What is the lifespan of this newly introduced contraceptive advice?
A 49-year-old multiparous woman with chronic PID presents with persistent lower abdominal pain. What is the most appropriate treatment?

Arrange the following sites of endometriosis in decreasing order of frequency of involvement:

 

  1. Pouch of Douglas
  2. Uterosacral ligament
  3. Broad ligament
  4. Ovary
  5. Fallopian tube
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4 > 1 > 3 > 2 > 5

 

  • Endometriosis refers to the presence of functional endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterine cavity.
  • It most commonly involves dependent pelvic structures where retrograde menstrual blood tends to collect.
  • The most frequent sites of endometriosis, in decreasing order of involvement, are:

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered an advantage of using norgestimate-containing oral contraceptives?

A 2-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of cyanosis. He became fussy and sweaty while taking his bottle, and his lips "turned blue" for several minutes during the feeding. The infant has had similar episodes during feeding and crying, but these resolved quickly. The patient was born at 39 weeks gestation, and his birth weight was average for gestational age. His weight gain has been slow, currently at the 5th percentile. On examination, the infant is ill-appearing, agitated, cyanotic, and tachypneic. Cardiac auscultation reveals a grade 2/6 crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and a single second heart sound. The patient is placed in a knee-chest position immediately. This maneuver improves the patient’s condition predominantly by which of the following mechanisms?
What is the minimum colony count (CFU/ml) required to diagnose catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI)?

choices.text: Increase in FEV1 > 12% after salbutamol inhalation

questions.text: All the following PFT findings in a child are suggestive of asthma except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Day-night variation of FEV1 > 15%

choices.text: PVA particles and glue are used as embolising agents
Ovarian failure is one possible complication
It can be done in nulliparous women

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding uterine artery embolization for fibroids?
questions.solution: Ans. D) It can be done in nulliparous women

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with coarctation of the aorta is posted for elective C-section. What is the preferred anesthesia in this scenario?

A 34-week G2P1L1 woman presents with bleeding per vaginam and abdominal pain for 4 hours. Vitals show Hb 6 g/dL, pulse 120/min, and BP 80/60 mmHg. On abdominal examination, uterus is tonically contracted and fetal heart sounds are absent. PV examination: cervix 2 cm dilated, 70% effaced, vertex at -2 station. The patient appears distressed and in shock. What is the best management option?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Emergency LSCS

 

Diagnosis: Abruptio Placentae (Severe abruption with fetal demise and maternal shock)

 

Key findings:

 

  • Painful vaginal bleeding
  • Uterus is hard and tender (tonically contracted)
  • Maternal shock disproportionate to visible blood loss (concealed hemorrhage)
  • Absent fetal heart sounds

 

These findings indicate placental abruption with concealed hemorrhage causing maternal hypovolemic shock.

 

Immediate Management:

 

  • The management goal is to save the mother by:

 

  1. Immediate resuscitation with IV fluids and blood transfusion.
  2. Expedite delivery to stop further bleeding — route depends on maternal condition and cervical status.

 

Here, the cervix is only 2 cm dilated, and vaginal delivery will take a long time.


Therefore, emergency cesarean section is indicated once the mother is stabilized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ARM + Oxytocin: Artificial rupture of membranes and oxytocin infusion are appropriate only when the cervix is favorable and the patient is stable, allowing vaginal delivery. In this case, the cervix is minimally dilated and patient is in shock, so this is unsafe.

 

Option B. Steroids followed by LSCS: Corticosteroids are used before 34 weeks to enhance fetal lung maturity if delivery can be delayed safely. Here, the patient is unstable, and the fetus is already dead. Steroids have no role.

 

Option D. Urgent ultrasound: The diagnosis of abruption is clinical; waiting for ultrasound delays treatment and increases maternal risk. Immediate resuscitation and delivery are priorities.

choices.text: Prolonged latent phase in a multipara is when it is over 12hrs.
Arrest of descent means no descent for over 1 hour
Minimum cervical dilation rate in nullipara is 1.2 cm/hr
Arrest of active phase means no dilation of 4hrs with adequate uterine contractions

questions.text: Which statement is false regarding the active phase of labor?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Prolonged latent phase in a multipara is when it is over 12hrs.

  1. Used to deliver the after coming head in breech

1.

During pregnancy, which of the following parameters increases?

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 38 weeks gestation undergoes spontaneous vaginal delivery. After an uncomplicated delivery of the fetus and placenta, a maternal laceration is noted at the posterior vaginal opening through the vaginal mucosa and submucosa. Which of the following structures is most likely damaged in this patient?
From which spinal segment is the sympathetic nerve supply to the ovary derived?
